thread.title: Chicago Cubs: Did Back to the Future predict World Series winner?
thread.title_full: Chicago Cubs: Did Back to the Future predict World Series winner?

author: Cameron Tomarchio
title: Chicago Cubs: Did Back to the Future predict World Series winner?
text:
Video Image Chicago Cubs fly past the St Louis Cardinals 1:07 MLB: The Chicago Cubs continue on the road to their first World Series since 1908, defeating the St Louis Cardinals 3-1 to claim their National League play-off series
October 14th 2015 7 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/ Did Back to the Future predict the Cubs would win the World Series?
Cameron Tomarchio news.com.au IT IS a tale so unlikely, Back to the Future predicted it just because of how ridiculous it sounded.
But was the movie right?
The Chicago Cubs, with the longest title drought of any North American sports team at 106 seasons, have defeated the St Louis Cardinals 6-4 to reach Major League Baseball’s National League finals.
It leaves the club — a perennial laughing stock — just one series away from reaching the World Series.
Javier Baez, Kyle Schwarber and Anthony Rizzo smacked home runs to power the long-suffering Cubs, who had never clinched a playoff series at home until taking this best-of-five matchup from the Cardinals three games to one.
“This means so much to the team, the city and to everyone involved with this organisation,” Rizzo said.
“We’re so happy right now. I can’t even put it into words.”
Back to the Future Part II sees Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) travel to the year 2015, and the Cubs winning the World Series was considered one of the movies more outlandish predictions.
“Wait a minute,” McFly says as he reads sports bulletin projected onto the side of a building.
“Who would have thought? A 100-1 shot,” an old man replies. “I wish I could go back to the beginning of the season and put some money on the Cubbies.”
Fans have been latching onto the Back to the Future link, dressing up as McFly and Doc.
Doc and Marty are here!! #LetsGo @Cubs pic.twitter.com/AoqyCNMlgN
— South Bend Cubs (@SBCubs) October 12, 2015 Back to the Future said Cubs would win in 2015! Just sayin. Now if I cud get a hoverboard for getting into my deer stand, that'd be awesome!
— Chipper Jones (@RealCJ10) October 14, 2015 The movie’s screenwriter, Bob Gales, said the Cubs winning the World Series was meant as a joke.
“Whether the Cubs make it or the Cubs don’t make it, the joke will still be funny,” Gale said.
“And if the Cubs do make it, then I’m a visionary.”
The Cubs, who had not won a playoff series since beating Atlanta in the 2003 National League first round, next face either the New York Mets or Los Angeles Dodgers to determine a berth in the World Series.
The Cubs, founded in 1870, have not won a World Series since 1908.
Wrigley Field, built in 1914, is among America’s most iconic sports venues, but the Cubs, who began playing there in 1916, had never before hosted a playoff victory celebration, clinching 1907 and 1908 World Series crowns in Detroit and a 2003 first-round triumph in Atlanta.
Wild celebrations as the Chicago Cubs defeat the Cardinals to win the NLDS at Wrigley Field. Source: Reuters
Pedro Strop reacts after recording the final out against St. Louis. Source: AFP
Hopes are building that this will finally be the season when the jinx ends, although there was late drama to be endured.
Matt Carpenter hit a two-out single in the ninth for St. Louis to bring rookie Stephen Piscotty, who homered in the first inning, to the plate as the tying run.
But Cubs relief pitcher Hector Rondon struck out Piscotty to end the game and ignite a raucous celebration.
“Hopefully this is just a taste of what’s about to come,” Rizzo said.
“We just beat the best team in baseball. The whole city is going to celebrate this.”
The Cubs have not even reached the World Series since 1945, when Detroit beat them in seven games.
Chicago lost all seven World Series appearances between 1908 and 1945 and failed to reach the championship showdown in six National League playoff trips since the World Series of 70 years ago.
— with AFP
